moxie

Interface Check<C extends Check<C,R>,R>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Cardinality<C>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    ClassCheck<C>, LambdaCheck<R>, ObjectCheck<T>

    public interface Check<C extends Check<C,R>,R>
extends Cardinality<C>
    Domain-specific language methods for setting out the details of a retrospective mock validation.

     

    Syntax Overview

    A typical Moxie check statement on a mock object looks like this:

    Moxie.check(mock).returned(Moxie.lt(100)).times(3).on().someMethod(Moxie.hasSubstring("foo"));
    It can be understood in four parts:

    The first bit: identify the mock
    We specify the mock or spy object on which we want to perform the check. This is done using the Moxie.check() method.
    The middle bit: add conditions
    Using the methods on the ObjectCheck interface, we can attach various additional conditions to the check - when and how many times the method should have been called, what it should have returned/thrown, etc. See the next section for an overview of the different categories of methods. Note that methods that go in this section of a check statement can appear in any order.
    The penultimate bit: create a proxy
    This returns a proxy object of the same type as the mock, on which we invoke the method we wish to check was called. Note that this may be done using the ObjectCheck.on(), ObjectCheck.when(), ObjectCheck.get() or ObjectCheck.got() methods. They perform exactly the same function; which you choose to call in any given situation is a matter of aesthetics.
    The last bit: specify the method
    We call the method we wish to check was called on the mock, with the parameters that should have been passed. Note that you can use calls to MoxieMatchers to do flexible matching on the parameters (specifying that a parameter can contain any value, will be less/greater than a certain value, will contain a certain substring, etc.) - see method descriptions on that class for more details.
    The syntax for specifying checks on static methods and constructorss is slightly different, but reads similarly - see documentation on the ClassCheck interface for further detail:

    Moxie.check(SomeClass.class).returned(Moxie.startsWith("x")).once().on("someStaticMethod", Moxie.endsWith("y"));
    Moxie.check(SomeClass.class).atLeast(3).onNew("constructor args or matchers");
    Finally, LambdaChecks let one perform checks on static methods and constructors with a refactorable syntax that goes well with Java 8 lambdas. (You can of course use this on older versions of Java, but the corresponding anonymous-inner-class syntax is more cumbersome.) Some examples:

    Moxie.check().returned(Moxie.lt(100)).times(3).on(() -> { mock.someMethod(Moxie.hasSubstring("foo")); });
    Moxie.check().returned(Moxie.startsWith("x")).once().on(() -> { SomeClass.someStaticMethod(Moxie.endsWith("y")); });
    Moxie.check().atLeast(3).on(() -> { new SomeClass("constructor args or matchers"); });
     

    Condition Syntax

    The "middle bit" of the check statement can contain zero or more condition-setting methods:

    setting the expected number of invocations (Cardinality methods)
    The Check interface extends the Cardinality interface; methods from this interface (like never(), atLeastOnce(), atLeast(int), atMost(int)) can be used to specify how many times the method should have been called.

    If none of these methods are invoked, the default behavior is once().

    negation: didNot()
    didNot() negates the sense of the check; an error will be raised if a method invocation (or set of invocations) is found that matches the check, rather than if one is not found.

    interaction with Expectations: unexpectedly()
    If unexpectedly() is specified, the check will only match method invocations that did not fulfill expectations (including stubs).

    Caveat: the ability to mix ahead-of-time expectation setting and after-the-fact checking in the same test is provided for completeness and as an experimental feature. Used carelessly, it is a sure way to render your tests incomprehensible and unmaintainable.

    associating checks with a Group: inGroup()
    By using a Group, checks can be made where method ordering is significant. (Checks do not pay any attention to the ordering of method calls otherwise.)

    checking returned/thrown values: returned() and threw()
    On spy objects (and mocks with esoteric handlers), returned() and threw() include the value returned/thrown by the method in the check. You can use MoxieMatchers methods to perform a flexible match.

    These methods have identically-functional aliases, returnValue() and throwException(), which give checks that use didNot() a nicer-sounding alternative syntax.

    Note that these methods cannot be used on final, private, static or constructor methods (thus they are only available on the ObjectCheck interface). The way these are implemented in Moxie involves using PowerMock to replace the original implementation of the method/constructor with a stub; as returned() and threw() are intended to verify the behavior of the underlying implementation in the mocked class, including them would make no sense.

     

    Subclasses

    Note that most of the useful methods on this class have been migrated to one of its three subclasses - please see the documentation of these classes for more detail:

    • ObjectCheck - for checking calls on most mock/spy objects in the traditional manner.
    • ClassCheck - for checking calls to static/constructor methods (reflection-based API).
    • LambdaCheck - lets one specify mock calls (either on individual mocks or to statics/constructors) using Java 8 lambda syntax.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      C didNot()
      Inverts the sense of the match; an error will be raised if a call to the specified method matching this check is found, rather than if one is not found.
      C inGroup(Group... group)
      Check that the method executed after any methods already successfully checked as part of the given group(s).
      C returned(R returnValue)
      Check that the relevant method returned the given value.
      C returnValue(R returnValue)
      Check that the relevant method returned the given value.
      C threw(Throwable throwable)
      Check that the relevant method threw the given Throwable.
      C throwException(Throwable throwable)
      Check that the relevant method threw the given Throwable.
      C unexpectedly()
      This check will only match invocations that did not match a previously specified expectation.

    • Method Detail

      • didNot

        C didNot()
        Inverts the sense of the match; an error will be raised if a call to the specified method matching this check is found, rather than if one is not found.

        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • unexpectedly

        C unexpectedly()
        This check will only match invocations that did not match a previously specified expectation.

        Only makes sense in conjunction with MoxieOptions.PERMISSIVE mocks.

        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • inGroup

        C inGroup(Group... group)
        Check that the method executed after any methods already successfully checked as part of the given group(s).

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Group interface for more details.

        This call will raise an error if any MoxieOptions.UNORDERED groups are specified.

        Parameters:
        group - one or more Groups
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • throwException

        C throwException(Throwable throwable)
        Check that the relevant method threw the given Throwable.

        Note that you can use the matcher methods to match on the exception object.

        Note also that that throwException() and threw() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        throwable - the Throwable thrown, or a matcher invocation
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • threw

        C threw(Throwable throwable)
        Check that the relevant method threw the given Throwable.

        Note that you can use the matcher methods to match on the exception object.

        Note also that that throwException() and threw() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        throwable - the Throwable thrown, or a matcher invocation
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • returnValue

        C returnValue(R returnValue)
        Check that the relevant method returned the given value.

        Note that you can use the matcher methods to match on the return value.

        Note also that that returnValue() and returned() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
